titleStmt.title: The remedie of unreasonableness. Or The substance of a speech intended at a conference or dispute, in Al-hallows the Great, London. Feb. 11. 1649. Exhibiting the brief heads of Mr John Goodwin's judgement, concerning the freeness fulness effectualness of the grace of God. As also concerning the bondage or servility of the will of man. Occasioned by an undue aspersion cast upon him; as (viz.) that he held free-will in opposition to free-grace.
titleStmt.author: Goodwin, John, 1594?-1665.

titleStmt.title: The remedie of unreasonableness. Or The substance of a speech intended at a conference or dispute, in Al-hallows the Great, London. Feb. 11. 1649. Exhibiting the brief heads of Mr John Goodwin's judgement, concerning the freeness fulness effectualness of the grace of God. As also concerning the bondage or servility of the will of man. Occasioned by an undue aspersion cast upon him; as (viz.) that he held free-will in opposition to free-grace.
titleStmt.author: Goodwin, John, 1594?-1665.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by John Macock, for Lodowick Lloyd, and Henry Cripps, and are to be sold at their shop in Popes head Alley,

notesStmt.note: A reply to a verbal attack by John Simpson.
The words "freeness .. effectualness" are enclosed in brackets on title page.
Annotation on Thomason copy: "Feb 22 1649"; the imprint date has been crossed out.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
